evidence_span: in both the cold-worked and cold-worked + annealed (24 h/560°C) conditions

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: in both the cold-worked and cold-worked + annealed (24 h/560°C) conditions

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: Cold-worked tubes consisted of deformed α-Zr grains with a network of β-Zr (~20 wt% Nb) surrounding the α-Zr grains

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: Annealing produced a decomposition of the β-Zr phase into α-Zr and β-Nb (~83 wt% Nb)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: Cold-worked tubing with Fe contents ≥500 ppm also contained a very small volume fraction of Zr(Fe) precipitates having a tetragonal structure

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: β-quenching during fabrication of the tubing appeared to suppress the precipitation of Zr(Fe)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: On annealing, both Zr(FeCr) and Zr(Fe) precipitates were formed

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: The Zr(FeCr)2 precipitates had either the C-15 cubic or C-14 hexagonal Laves phase structure

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: It is proposed that on annealing at 560°C the β-Zr phase (containing Fe and Cr in solution) transforms to α-Zr + β-Nb + Zr(FeCr)2 phases

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: Zr-2.5 wt% Nb (hereafter referred to as Zr-2.5Nb) alloy is used in CANDU-PHW type reactors

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk1
evidence_span: The fabrication process for the tubing had been the 'standard': hot extrusion at 850°C, followed by cold-working (20 to 30%) to size, and a final autoclave stress-relief at 400°C for 24 h

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: Eight tubes were heat-treated at $5 6 0 ^ { \circ } C$ for $^ { 2 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ to produce significant decomposition of ${ \beta } { \cdot } Z { \mathbf { r } }$ to $\mathsf { \beta - N b }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: The intent of this treatment was to simulate possible in-reactor decomposition of $\beta \mathrm { - } Z \mathbf { r }$ , observed in removed $\mathbf { Z r { - } } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N b }$ pressure tubes.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: After annealing, the dislocation density is reduced

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra for all heat-treated samples showed diffraction peaks at diffraction angles $2 \theta = 3 8 . 6 4 ^ { \circ }$ and $5 5 . 7 4 ^ { \circ }$ .These correspond to the first two reflections (110) and (200) of bcc $\beta { \cdot } \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra for all heat-treated samples showed diffraction peaks at diffraction angles $2 \theta = 3 8 . 6 4 ^ { \circ }$ and $5 5 . 7 4 ^ { \circ }$ .These correspond to the first two reflections (110) and (200) of bcc $\beta { \cdot } \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: Thus it is probable that all of the $\scriptstyle \mathbf { \beta - Z r }$ has transformed to $\mathbf { \alpha - Z r }$ and $\beta$ -Nb after heating for $^ { 2 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ at $5 6 0 ^ { \circ } C$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: The size of $\beta$ -Nb particles are typically a few hundred nanometers in diameter.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: EDX analysis of extracted particles from the heat-treated samples confirmed them to be $\mathbf { \beta - N b }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: The peak corresponding to the $\mathbf { K } _ { \alpha }$ $( 1 6 . 5 8 1 \ \mathrm { k e V } )$ and $\mathbf { K } _ { \beta }$ (18.614 $\mathbf { k e V } )$ emissions from the $\mathsf { N b }$ present in the $\beta$ -Nb can be readily detected.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: The peak corresponding to the $\mathbf { K } _ { \alpha }$ $( 1 6 . 5 8 1 \ \mathrm { k e V } )$ and $\mathbf { K } _ { \beta }$ (18.614 $\mathbf { k e V } )$ emissions from the $\mathsf { N b }$ present in the $\beta$ -Nb can be readily detected.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: The $\mathrm { L } _ { \alpha }$ emission line for Nb $( 2 . 1 6 6 ~ \mathrm { k e V } )$ cannot readily be seen

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: Zr, Fe, and $\mathrm { C r }$ is not homogeneous, and that the composition is quite different for each particle of $\beta$ -Nb.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: Some particles contain $\mathrm { C r }$ in addition to Nb and $Z \mathbf { r }$ , whereas others contain Fe and no Cr. Some particles contain only Nb and $Z \mathbf { r }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: the $\mathsf { Z r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathsf { N b }$ alloys contain little Fe and $\mathrm { C r }$ (e.g., $9 2 9 ~ \mathsf { p p m }$ Fe and $1 1 4 { \mathrm { ~ p p m ~ C r } }$ in tube D1301)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: the $\mathsf { Z r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathsf { N b }$ alloys contain little Fe and $\mathrm { C r }$ (e.g., $9 2 9 ~ \mathsf { p p m }$ Fe and $1 1 4 { \mathrm { ~ p p m ~ C r } }$ in tube D1301)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk4
evidence_span: it is considered that the Fe and $\mathrm { C r }$ are concentrated in $\beta$ -Nb rather than in $\alpha { - } Z \ r$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: A comparison of the emission spectra from the $\beta { - } Z \tau$ phase in the as-fabricated tubing with that from the $\beta$ -Nb phase in the heat-treated tubing shows that, whereas the intensity of emission from Nb are much stronger than those from $Z \mathbf { r }$ for the heat-treated alloys, the K emissions $\mathrm { ( K _ { \alpha } = 1 5 . 7 4 4 ~ k e V }$ , $\mathrm { K _ { \mathrm { 8 } } ~ = ~ 1 7 . 6 6 0 ~ k e V } )$ and the L emission of $Z \mathbf { r }$ are higher than those for Nb in the $\beta { - } Z \mathbf { r }$ phase in the as-fabricated alloys.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: A comparison of the emission spectra from the $\beta { - } Z \tau$ phase in the as-fabricated tubing with that from the $\beta$ -Nb phase in the heat-treated tubing shows that, whereas the intensity of emission from Nb are much stronger than those from $Z \mathbf { r }$ for the heat-treated alloys, the K emissions $\mathrm { ( K _ { \alpha } = 1 5 . 7 4 4 ~ k e V }$ , $\mathrm { K _ { \mathrm { 8 } } ~ = ~ 1 7 . 6 6 0 ~ k e V } )$ and the L emission of $Z \mathbf { r }$ are higher than those for Nb in the $\beta { - } Z \mathbf { r }$ phase in the as-fabricated alloys.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: This, again, is in agreement with the phase diagram, with $\beta { - } Z \up$ containing ${ \sim } 2 0 \mathrm { { w t } } \%$ Nb.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: These spectra for $\mathsf { { \beta { - } Z r } }$ generally also indicate a higher Fe (and $\mathrm { C r }$ content for the $\mathsf { \beta } \mathsf { - } \mathsf { Z } \mathsf { r }$ phase than for the $\beta$ -Nb phase.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: Intermetallic precipitates were formed at the $\alpha { - } Z \gamma$ grain boundaries along with the $\mathsf { \beta } \mathrm { - } \mathsf { N b }$ in all heat-treated materials.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: Selected area electron diffraction identified these precipitates to be the $Z \mathrm { r } ( \mathrm { F e } _ { x } { \bf C r } _ { 1 - x } ) _ { 2 }$ Laves phase type, where $x$ varied from 0 to 1.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: The $Z \mathbf { r } ( \mathbf { F e C r } ) _ { 2 }$ precipitates with a cubic structure were found in heat-treated samples of tubes 185, D1162, and D1301.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: The size of these precipitates is about $1 5 0 \mathrm { n m }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: The electron diffraction pattern for zone axes [134], [123], [112], [145], [132] and [143], as well as those for [011], [134], [123] and [112], indicated that the precipitates had the C15 cubic structure.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: $Z \mathbf { r } ( \mathbf { F e C r } ) _ { 2 }$ precipitates with a hexagonal structure were also found in heat-treated tubes 185, D1162, and D1301.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: All of the interplanar angles and spacings measured from diffraction patterns with [130], [140], [010], [130] and [120] orientations confirm the precipitate to be of the C14 hexagonal $Z \mathbf { r } ( \mathbf { F e C r } ) _ { 2 }$ Laves phase type.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: the chromium content in these tubes is only about $1 0 0 ~ \mathsf { p p m }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: A third type of intermetallic precipitate was found in heat-treated samples of tube D1301. These precipitates were identified as the $\mathrm { Z r } _ { 2 } \mathrm { F e }$ phase.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: has only been positively identified in tubes with Fe contents greater than about 500 ppm [14]

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: Tubes D168, D1345, D1260, D587 and C170 contain less than 729 ppm Fe and less than $8 0 \ { \mathsf { p p m } } \ { \mathsf { C r } }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: Tubes D168, D1345, D1260, D587 and C170 contain less than 729 ppm Fe and less than $8 0 \ { \mathsf { p p m } } \ { \mathsf { C r } }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: After annealing at $5 6 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ for $^ { 2 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk5
evidence_span: The tubes in which the $\mathrm { Z r } _ { 2 } \mathrm { F e }$ precipitates were found were characterized by two features, namely an Fe content ${ \gtrsim } 5 0 0$ ppm

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk6
evidence_span: Heating of the as-fabricated, coldworked tubing for $2 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ }$ at $5 6 0 \%$ produced a breakdown of the $\beta$ -Zr ${ \sim } 2 0 ~ \mathrm { w t } \%$ Nbnetwork surrounding the elongated $\alpha$ -Zr grains to discrete particles of $\beta$ -Nb $\sim 8 3 \ \mathrm { w t } \%$ Nb).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk6
evidence_span: Heating of the as-fabricated, coldworked tubing for $2 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ }$ at $5 6 0 \%$ produced a breakdown of the $\beta$ -Zr ${ \sim } 2 0 ~ \mathrm { w t } \%$ Nbnetwork surrounding the elongated $\alpha$ -Zr grains to discrete particles of $\beta$ -Nb $\sim 8 3 \ \mathrm { w t } \%$ Nb).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk6
evidence_span: At the same time as the $\mathsf { \beta - N b }$ particles are formed, there is an associated precipitation of a small volume fraction of $Z \mathbf { r } ( \mathrm { F e C r } ) _ { 2 }$ Laves phase precipitates.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk6
evidence_span: If during reactor operation at ${ \sim } 3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ there is a breakdown of the ${ \beta } { \cdot } Z \tau$ phase to $\beta$ -Nb and the concurrent precipitation of $Z \mathrm { { r } ( F e C r ) _ { \vec { \tau } } }$ , the corrosion/hydriding resistance could be affected.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk6
evidence_span: The microstructure of cold-worked $Z \mathrm { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathrm { N b }$ pressure tubing consists of elongated $\alpha - \mathrm { Z r }$ grains with a $\beta { - } Z \operatorname { r }$ $( \sim 2 0 \ \mathrm { w t } \%$ Nb) network at the $\mathbf { \alpha } \mathbf { - } \mathbf { } \mathbf { } \mathbf { } Z \mathbf { r }$ grain boundaries.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk6
evidence_span: A very small volume fraction of $\mathsf { Z r } _ { \vec { \mathbf { \imath } } } \mathrm { F e }$ precipitates are also present in tubes containing greater than about 500 ppm Fe.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk6
evidence_span: The $\beta$ -quenching during processing of the tubes appeared to suppress $\mathrm { Z r } _ { 2 } \mathrm { F e }$ precipitation in the high Fe content tubes.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk6
evidence_span: A larger $\alpha { - } Z \tau$ grain size also appeared to promote the formation of $\mathsf { Z r } _ { \mathfrak { L } } \mathsf { F e }$ precipitates.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk6
evidence_span: On heating the cold-worked tubing for $2 4 \ \mathrm { h }$ at $5 6 0 \%$ , the $\beta { - } Z { \boldsymbol { \mathrm { r } } }$ decomposes into discrete particles of $\beta$ -Nb $( - 8 3 \ \mathrm { w t } \% \ \mathrm { N b } )$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: most of the Fe is concentrated in the $\beta$ -phase in an as-fabricated $Z \mathrm { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathrm { N b }$ pressure tube

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: the $\beta$ -phase (containing about $2 0 \mathrm { \ w t \% }$ Nb) is approximately $1 3 \%$ of the total volume fraction

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: the Fe concentration in the $\beta$ -phase is typically on the order of 1 $\mathbf { w t } \%$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: Heat treatment sufficient to totally decompose the $\beta$ -phase. for example $5 0 0 ^\circ C$ for $7 5 0 \ \mathrm { h }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: results in the formation of $\beta$ -Nb $8 6 ~ \mathrm { w t } \%$ Nb)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: Irradiation in a CANDU reactor results in dispersion of the Fe from the $\beta$ -phase

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: $\beta$ -Nb precipitates are formed from supersaturated solid solution in the $\alpha$ -phase in the peak flux section of the reactor

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: after irradiation at $2 7 0 ^\circ C$ to a fluence of $8 . 5 \ \times \ I 0 ^ { 2 5 } n m ^ { - 2 }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: There are many more (estimated 10 to 50 times) β-Nb particles than Laves phase precipitates in the heat-treated material

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: the lattice parameters that have been given for the hexagonal $( Z \mathrm { r N b } ) _ { 3 } \mathrm { F e }$ phase $( a = 0 . 5 4 \ \mathrm { n m }$ and $c = 0 . 8 8 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ )

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: the lattice parameters that have been given for the hexagonal $( Z \mathrm { r N b } ) _ { 3 } \mathrm { F e }$ phase $( a = 0 . 5 4 \ \mathrm { n m }$ and $c = 0 . 8 8 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ )

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk7
evidence_span: heat treatment (24 h at 560°C)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk8
evidence_span: Binary Zr-Fe and Nb-Fe phase diagrams suggest that β-Zr should dissolve ~3% Fe. while β-Nb should only contain ~1% Fe.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk8
evidence_span: Binary Zr-Fe and Nb-Fe phase diagrams suggest that β-Zr should dissolve ~3% Fe. while β-Nb should only contain ~1% Fe.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk8
evidence_span: the EDX values for Fe in the β-Nb indicate a value of about 1.5 wt% Fe. which is in quite good agreement with the value of ~1% Fe you quote from the Zr-Fe and Nb-Fe phase diagrams.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk8
evidence_span: The Fe content of the β-Nb particles did. however, vary from particle to particle.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk8
evidence_span: Fewer EDX determinations were made for Fe in the β-Zr phase. but indications were that it was higher than for the β-Nb phase.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_014_chunk8
evidence_span: Tubular samples of Zircaloy-4 clad, of the standard 17x17 PWR design, in the cold worked, stress relieved condition, with a mean wall thickness ξ = 580 μm

evidence_span: samples machined to reduce their wall thickness to 200 and 80 μm, respectively
